probe.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to ask questions in order to find things out, especially things that other people do not want you to know
probe.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Police probed claims that he had sold drugs.
I donâ€™t want to probe too deeply into your personal affairs.
probe.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to look for something or examine something, using a long thin object
probe.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Jules probed the mud gingerly with a stick.
probe.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a long thin metal instrument that doctors and scientists use to examine parts of the body
probe.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: an investigation in which many questions are asked to discover the truth about something
probe.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a very thorough examination of something that has happened
probe.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The probe focuses on an unauthorized bid placed by the company two months ago.
The agency is conducting a wide-ranging probe into possible collusion and fraud.
federal probes of trading practices at the Chicago exchanges
probe.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to ask very detailed questions to find something out, especially things people do not want you to know
probe.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: To probe further, I called economist John Mueller.
The scale of losses is prompting regulators to probe the portfolios of US banks.
